DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Arrives For Historic Two-Day Visit
With AM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze arrived Sunday for a historic two-day visit to visit NATO headquarters and sign a trade and economic cooperation accord with the European Community. Shevardnadze was greeted at Abelag Airport by Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens. He made no statement upon arrival. On Tuesday, Shevardnadze will pay a 90-minute visit to the headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for talks with NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner and the ambassadors of the member nations. Officials have said there is no fixed agenda for the talks at alliance headquarters and have described it as a courtesy call that is indicative of the new East-West climate. On Monday, Shevardnadze will meet with the foreign ministers of the 12-nation EC trade bloc and sign a cooperation agreement. He also will meet separately with Belgian Prime Minister Wilfried Martens and King Baudouin and will discuss the reforms sweeping acrosss Eastern Europe with government ministers during a meeting that will continue over lunch. The economic agreement with the EC was concluded Nov. 27 and provides for a gradual lifting of EC import quotas on Soviet industrial goods by 1995. The accord also lists a dozen areas in which the EC and the Soviet Union plan to establish economic cooperation. These include science and technology, banking, transport, agriculture, environmental protection, energy, raw materials and mining. The accord excludes trade in goods that are considered militarily sensitive, according to EC sources. The EC-Soviet accord is the fourth between the community and an East European nation since the EC and the Moscow-led Comecon trade bloc signed a mutual recognition accord June 25, 1988. Since then the EC has concluded trade and economic cooperation accords with the Soviet Union, Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia. The EC's trade with Eastern Europe is small. It totalled only $56 billion in 1987, the last year for which complete figures are available and about half of that was with the Soviet Union. By comparison, the EC's trade with Switzerland that year was some $66 billion.
